metadata.case_name: N. M. Rayalu Iyer & Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: M/s. N. M. Rayaloo Iyer & Sons (assessees) is a firm carrying on business principally in dyes and chemicals as chief representatives in South India of products of Imperial Chemical Industries (India) Ltd. (I.C.I.), under the name Colours Trading Company with head office at Madura and thirteen branch offices.

Business originally carried on in partnership by three brothers: N. M. R. Venkatakrishna Iyer, N. M. R. Subbaraman and N. M. R. Krishnamurti. On April 13, 1946, N. M. R. Subbaraman retired and share of N. M. R. Venkatakrishna Iyer taken over by N. M. R. Venkatakrishna Iyer Sons Ltd., but business continued in original name.

N. M. R. Mahadevan (son of N. M. R. Venkatakrishna Iyer) employed as General Manager of Colours Trading Co. By letter dated April 17, 1940, agreed to pay him Rs. 1,800 per annum and 5% of net profits of Colours Trading Company (gross profits minus salaries, wages, other outgoings, without deduction for capital). By letter dated March 30, 1943, salary fixed at Rs. 3,000 per annum and commission enhanced to 12-1/2% of net profits.
Branch offices managed by local managers and assistant managers paid monthly salary, annual and special bonus, dearness allowance.

Assessees received commission from I.C.I. at rates varying between 7-1/2% and 12% on different products. With effect from April 1, 1944, I.C.I. allowed special emergency commission of 5% on all dyes and dyestuffs, increased to 15% on sales on or after March 1, 1945, reduced to 10% on sales on or after September 1, 1946.

Appeals relate to Excess Profits Tax for chargeable accounting periods ending April 13, 1943; April 12, 1944; April 12, 1945; March 31, 1946; and Business Profits Tax for periods ending April 12, 1946; March 31, 1947; April 13, 1947; March 31, 1948; April 12, 1948.

Assessees claimed payments to employees in years 1942-43 to 1947-48 of share in special emergency commission received from I.C.I., in addition to monthly salary, dearness allowance, general and special bonus.
I.C.I. by letter dated January 24, 1944, recommended 1% out of 5% emergency commission passed on to sub-distributors. By letter dated February 23, 1945, recommended 6% out of 15% to sub-distributors.
Assessees claimed to have paid commission to employees at rates 1-1/2% to 4%, later 2% to 7-1/2%, some up to 12%, even when turnover < Rs. 1,00,000 (condition in service agreements).

In year ending April 12, 1945, revision of salaries: dearness allowance and special bonus >50% of basic salary, annual bonus = annual salary, total at least 2.1 times enhanced basic salary, plus commission >12 times basic in some cases.

Income-tax Officer disallowed 12-1/2% net profits to Mahadevan for 1943-44, 1944-45; disallowed commission to branch managers/employees for 1945-46 to 1948-49, added back for Income-tax, Excess Profits Tax, Business Profits Tax.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed 5% or 12-1/2% after deduction of taxes (higher), confirmed by Tribunal for Mahadevan; Tribunal confirmed disallowance of employee commissions.

Tribunal referred questions to High Court under s.66(1) Income-tax Act r/w s.21 Excess Profits Tax Act: Referred Case No.44/1953 (questions on s.10(2)(xv), Mahadevan commission, employee commissions); Referred Case No.53/1952 (questions on deduction of EPT before Mahadevan commission, reasonableness under Rule 12 Sch.1 EPT Act, branch managers commission).

High Court held deductions under s.10(2)(x) not (2)(xv) Income-tax Act; for EPT, allowed under s.10(2)(x) and Rule 12 Sch.1; for Mahadevan, EPT not deductible before commission following Punjab HC; for employees, after supplementary statement, allowed entire claim as reasonable.

Emergency commission received and paid: 1945-46: Rs.1,28,533 rec., Rs.1,00,715 paid; 1946-47: Rs.3,20,391 rec., Rs.2,44,698 paid; 1947-48: Rs.3,15,934 rec., Rs.1,28,506 paid; 1948-49: Rs.3,70,964 rec., Rs.1,75,079 paid.
Examples: Themaswamy commission Rs.15,000-23,000 (salary Rs.2,100); K.N. Rajagopalachari Rs.16,000-12,000 (salary Rs.1,260); etc.

EPT Officer findings: employees amply remunerated; no demand for increase; commission credited not paid; agreements fabricated; not wholly for business; disproportionate (error in profit figure but not affecting conclusion). Profits 1943-44 dyes: Rs.99,435, commission claimed Rs.1,00,715.

legal_issues.text: Whether in computing net profits for 12-1/2% commission to Mahadevan, Excess Profits Tax is to be deducted before calculation.

Whether commission payments to branch managers and employees out of emergency commission are deductible as reasonable and necessary under Rule 12 Sch.1 Excess Profits Tax Act / s.10(2)(x) Income-tax Act.
Whether ITO precluded from inquiring if payment wholly and exclusively for business under s.10(2)(xv) Income-tax Act.
Whether commission to Mahadevan wholly and exclusively for business.

petitioner_arguments.text: Commission payments to employees shared from emergency commission as recommended by I.C.I., even above minima, reasonable given market conditions, black-marketing; employees as sub-distributors; turnover conditions not strictly applied; entire claim deductible under s.10(2)(x) IT Act and Rule 12 Sch.1 EPT Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10(2)(x) Income-tax Act; Rule 12 Sch.1 Excess Profits Tax Act

petitioner_arguments.text: For Mahadevan, net profits per agreement exclude EPT as per commercial accountancy.
At least minima recommended by I.C.I. deductible.

respondent_arguments.text: Employees amply remunerated by salary, DA, bonuses (total >12 times salary); no need for extra incentive as dyes in short supply; no sub-distributors, so I.C.I. recommendation inapplicable; commissions disproportionate, credited not paid, agreements fabricated; not reasonable/necessary; to dissipate profits.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 12 Sch.1 Excess Profits Tax Act; s.10(2)(x) Income-tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: For Mahadevan, EPT deductible before commission as part of outgoings/net profits.

court_reasoning.text: For Mahadevan commission: Interpretation of agreement - net profits = gross profits minus salaries, wages, other outgoings (not restricted to commercial; includes EPT as tax on profits itself, divisible profits after EPT). Distinguished Delhi Flour Mills as different agreement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: EPT not deductible before computing 12-1/2% commission; outgoings include EPT.

court_reasoning.text: Deductions for employee commissions permissible under s.10(2)(x) IT Act for Income-tax (unchallenged). For EPT/BPT, via s.21 EPT Act applying s.10 IT Act modified by Sch.1 Rule 12: no deduction for expenses excess of reasonable/necessary re business requirements/actual services.
court_reasoning.key_observation: EPT Officer/Tribunal decide reasonableness objectively, subject to appeal; HC advisory jurisdiction, cannot reappraise evidence or substitute view.

court_reasoning.text: EPT Officer/Tribunal findings supported by evidence: ample remuneration, disproportionate payments (e.g. commission > profits), paid despite low turnover, no sub-distributors so I.C.I. minima inapplicable directly; commercial expediency viewed per business needs/services.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Disallowance justified under Rule 12; HC erred in reappreciating evidence.

court_reasoning.text: HC should answer questions on facts found, direct taxing authorities if legal error, not set aside or substitute.

holdings.text: In computing 12-1/2% commission to Mahadevan, Excess Profits Tax not deductible from profits beforehand; net profits mean divisible profits after EPT.

Disallowance of commission to branch managers/employees justified as not reasonable/necessary under Rule 12 Sch.1 EPT Act; taxing authorities' view supported by evidence, HC cannot interfere by reappreciating.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi v. Delhi Flour Mills Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Different agreement; there net profits meant divisible after EPT, but here agreement specifies outgoings without excluding taxes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi v. Delhi Flour Mills Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: HC followed this for no deduction of EPT before commission; SC holds otherwise on agreement interpretation.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Deductions for commission/bonus to employees under (2)(x); inquiry into business purpose under (2)(xv); reference to HC.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies IT Act s.10 with modifications; profits per Sch.1; no deduction for unreasonable expenses re business/services.

statutes_cited.name: Business Profits Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Supersedes EPT Act post 30.3.1946; similar provisions on profits and deductions.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed Appeal No.494/1958 (EPT appeals), reversed High Court on disallowance of employee commissions being unjustified, held Tribunal correct in disallowing under Rule 12; on Mahadevan, EPT not deductible before commission. Appeal No.495/1958 not specified fully but context similar. No order as to costs.
outcome.relief_granted: None; appeals allowed affirming tax authorities.

key_quotes.text: "the deduction to be allowed... does not depend upon any subjective satisfaction of the Excess Profits Tax Officer, but on objective standards as to what is reasonable and necessary having regard to the requirements of the business"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines test under Rule 12 Sch.1 EPT Act

key_quotes.text: "It is for him subject to review by the Tribunal to decide whether the deduction is reasonable and necessary... The jurisdiction which the High Court exercises... is merely advisory"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "commercial expediency must be viewed in the light of the requirements of the business and the actual services rendered by the persons concerned. Any abstract consideration of commercial expediency is out of place."
key_quotes.speaker: court
